Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Advanced Vehicle Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research of the planned I/UCRC for Advanced Vehicle Manufacturing aims to integrate multiple universities and disciplines to advance research that is intended to extend knowledge in the fields of smart assembly, logistics, and process diagnostics through data analytics and statistical modeling. Moreover, a better fundamental understanding of adapting emerging manufacturing methods and advanced materials with environmentally friendly (waste, fuel, emissions) vehicle designs will be explored. Research will also include an improved understanding and integration of the health, safety, and environmental issues of emerging manufacturing techniques.

Vehicle manufacturing is a sector of significant economic impact to the U.S., especially to the southeast. The Center intends to address the major challenges faced in advanced vehicle manufacturing and in the process have a major economic impact. With the cross-disciplinary expertise of the faculty and industry support, the center will also provide opportunities for interdisciplinary education. Workforce development and cross-training will be addressed through collaboration with a consortium of community colleges that work closely with the auto industry. The research team has significant involvement in diversity, veterans and K-12 outreach initiatives and the mentoring of graduate and undergraduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The consortium of Auburn University (AU), University of Alabama at Huntsville (UAH) and Tennessee Tech University (TT) seeks to establish the I/UCRC for Advanced Vehicle Manufacturing. This project requested a planning grant to establish a meeting between industry and the consortium of the universities to develop the initial research agenda for the center. Over the past one year, we delivered the following:

 

1-  Conducted the planning meeting on November 4th-5th, 2014 at the Adtran facility in Huntsville, AL. The meeting involved participation from the three universities, NSF, and over 25 governmental and industry organizations. The meeting involved the evaluation of 10 proposed research projects and discussion of how the different industry members can benefit from joining the consortium.

2-  Hosted three regional industry-government-academia roundtables at each of the three sites. The attendee list included organizations such as: NASA, Amrdec, Dynetics, 3M, Boeing, Toyota, Lockheed Martin, Chrysler, Mercedes-Benz, Hyundai, Kia, and their suppliers. The feedback from these meetings lead to developing the projects discussed in the planning meeting.

3-  Engaged the state and city organizations in these meetings with representation from the: Auburn Economic Development Council, Alabama Automotive Manufacturing Association, Georgia Automotive Manufacturing Association, Tennessee Automotive Manufacturing Association, Business Council of Alabama and Economic Development for the State of Alabama.

4-  Disseminated the results and efforts of our meetings through a number of different media outlets, e.g. ABC news and Business Alabama.

5-  Constructed a website to disseminate and publicized for the SAAV consortium, see www.saav.center.

6-  Conducted over 10 site visits to engage several of the top OEMs in the best strategies for launching the center and how to shape the research projects for their benefit.

7-  Held two meetings with Alabama state officials: a- Greg Canfield (Director of Commerce for the State) and b- Bill Taylor (President of the Economic Development Partnership of Alabama) to solicit their political support in engaging the OEMs and publicizing for the center.

8-  Organized an education roundtable where we invited many of the SAAV targeted company to discuss how to strengthen our current curriculum to meet the current and future needs of an evolving manufacturing sector.

9-  Developed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) document that will be signed by the universities and the members, if the SAAV center is granted a Phase I center by NSF.

10-  Finalized the membership agreement. NSF and the legal teams of all three universities have approved this document.

 

We are now working on the draft proposal for the Phase I center which we will submit to NSF in the fall. We have several organizations that have allotted the $50,000 membership fee for their 2015-2016 budget year and/or have verbally committed to join the center if it is funded by NSF. We expect to have at least 15 commitment letters across the 3 universities before we submit the proposal for the Phase 1 center in the fall. The research and economic impacts of the centers have been widely acknowledged by state officials and manufacturing associations in our previous meetings. We are looking forward to continue to support the growth of this pivotal sector of the Southern states' economy.
